question_text:
Read this sentence from lines 10 and 11 of the story.
'I kicked and soared and pranced and whirled, stepped and twirled and spun and flew, tripped and skipped and skimmed and sailed, all over that stage.'
The author most likely includes this description of Kathleen's dancing to
options: emphasize that the dance ends quickly
demonstrate Kathleen's desire for recognition
provide an image of a spirited performance
demonstrate Kathleen's skills as a dancer

question_text:
Read this sentence from lines 11 through 14 of the story.
'I hardly knew where I was, and I was completely oblivious to the audience, the strange hall, even the adjudicator, though I knew she must be out there somewhere in the blur of humanity beyond the stage, watching carefully and taking notes.'
What is the meaning of the phrase 'oblivious to' as it is used in this sentence?
options: unaware of
confused by
scornful of
afraid of

question_text: What do lines 10 through 17 mostly show about Kathleen?
options: Her confidence in her abilities helps her to remember her routine.
Her delight in dancing allows her to briefly forget her concerns.
She tries to ignore the unfamiliar setting and the audience.
She avoids people who are critical about her appearance.

question_text: Lines 36 through 42 mainly develop a central idea of the story by revealing
options: the importance of being able to communicate effectively
that Kathleen has lost interest in the conversation because of her success
that Kathleen's success is meaningful only if she can share it with her family
the significance of the support of family members even when they are absent

question_text: Which detail from the story best shows why Polly is important to Kathleen?
options: Polly can best describe Kathleen's dance to her mam.
Polly allows Kathleen to receive praise from her teacher.
Polly made Kathleen's dress using her own curtain fabric.
Polly inspired Kathleen to participate in the dance recital.

question_text:
Read this sentence from lines 49 through 51 of the story.
'I kept on smiling, and at the same time I was trying to look around Mrs. Maguire's bulk to see if I could catch a glimpse of Polly's flying figure and wide smile.'
This sentence suggests that Kathleen
options: is surprised by her teacher's presence
hopes to avoid chatting after her performance
is trying to be polite even though she is distracted
feels uncomfortable due to her teacher's compliments

question_text: How does the author establish the point of view differently in lines 1 through 32 as compared to lines 33 through 61?
options: by portraying the narrator's actions rather than sharing only the narrator's feelings
by describing the narrator's inner thoughts rather than sharing the inner thoughts of all the characters
by revealing the narrator's intentions through description instead of using description to share the opinions of all the characters
by revealing the narrator's thoughts only through description instead of through both description and dialogue

question_text: What does most of the poem describe?
options: the sounds of evening
animals preparing for nightfall
creatures hunting for food at night
the way the weather changes at sunset

question_text:
Read lines 1 through 3 of the poem.
'Oh, pleasant eventide!
Clouds on the western side
Grow grey and greyer hiding the warm sun:'
Which words best describe the tone that the poet creates at the beginning of the poem?
options: concern for warmth
surprised alarm at day's end
enthusiasm for the time of day
disapproval of the weather pattern

question_text:
Read lines 6 and 7 of the poem. Then read this dictionary entry for 'screen.'
'screen v. 1. to provide with a means to exclude insects 2. to shelter or conceal from view 3. to separate or sort 4. to use a method to determine suitability for a task'
Which definition best matches the meaning of 'screened' as it is used in lines 6 and 7?
options: definition 1
definition 2
definition 3
definition 4

question_text: Which lines provide the best evidence that events in nature are repeated over many years?
options: 'The very squirrel leaps from bough to bough / But lazily; pauses; and settles now / Where once he stored his food.' (lines 8 through 10)
'Nibbling his fill he stops from time to time / And listens where he sits.' (lines 19 and 20)
'Hark! that's the nightingale, / Telling the selfsame tale / Her song told when this ancient earth was young:' (lines 31 through 33)
'Through all the hours of night until the dawn / They sleep, forgetting fear.' (lines 44 and 45)

question_text: Which lines of the poem best demonstrate a gradual change that occurs during the evening?
options: lines 11 through 13
lines 16 through 20
lines 44 and 45
lines 54 and 55

question_text: Which word best describes most of the evening activity mentioned in the poem?
options: busy
lonely
strained
cooperative

question_text: Which lines best show that the night is different from the evening?
options: lines 1 through 5
lines 11 through 15
lines 26 through 30
lines 56 through 60

question_text: Lines 6 through 14 are important to the article because they
options: show the potential effects of reading over time
highlight the value of scientific research
emphasize the challenges beginning readers face
provide examples of the problems scientists face

question_text: Why is it important for parents to encourage reading at a young age?
options: Children are more likely than adults to follow stories all the way through.
Children are more likely than adults to use technology for information.
Children have longer attention spans than college students and older adults.
Children can more easily grasp new ideas and abilities than adults.

question_text: What is the meaning of the word 'simulate' as it is used in line 34 of the article?
options: to expect
to illustrate
to remember
to imitate

question_text: How do lines 45 through 53 illustrate possible ways to prevent brain disease?
options: by including the positive effects of certain activities on the brain
by describing how harmful substances form in the brain
by emphasizing the importance of brain scans for older adults
by proving that brain-based activities should be enjoyed by adults

question_text: How does the author support John Stein's claim that 'Reading exercises the whole brain' (line 26)?
options: by describing how other physical functions in the body work
by explaining which parts of the brain connect to senses
by explaining how functions of the brain are triggered
by describing a new method of creating pathways

question_text: Which statement best conveys the central idea of the article?
options: 'I'm a novelist-I've written five books for teenagers and it's obviously in my interest to encourage people to read.' (lines 1 and 2)
'But there's increasing evidence that reading for pleasure isn't just another leisure pursuit, or merely a way of improving literacy skills and factual knowledge.' (lines 3 and 4)
'When we 'get lost' in a good book, we're doing more than simply following a story.' (line 28)
'As the old saying goes: 'You're never alone with a book.'' (lines 36 and 37)

question_text: What is the author's main purpose for writing the article?
options: to encourage teens to read books that she has written
to convince people that reading is a worthwhile activity
to demonstrate why reading is a good form of entertainment
to show the negative effects of playing games instead of reading

question_text: How do lines 18 through 21 build on the idea introduced in lines 10 through 13?
options: by showing a relationship between DNA and plant growth
by showing how changes in DNA can help weeds as well as crops
by showing that weeds continue to resist farmers' attempts to kill them
by showing how glyphosate is a long-term solution to the problem of weeds

question_text: What is the meaning of the phrase 'impossibly improbable' as it is used in lines 21 through 23?
options: usually certain
highly unlikely
extremely slow
rarely noteworthy

question_text: Which conclusion is best supported by lines 27 through 32?
options: The DNA of weeds evolves rapidly.
Changes to the DNA of plants can occur by chance.
Greater quantities of glyphosate are required to kill weeds.
Plants evolve more quickly in some parts of the world than in others.

question_text: Which statement best describes the main idea of the section titled 'Winning the lottery'?
options: Farmers used glyphosate for many years on millions of hectares of crops.
The odds of any one person winning the lottery are tiny.
Many people expected glyphosate to work forever.
Several kinds of weeds developed a resistance to glyphosate.

question_text: The section titled 'Copy that' relates to the section titled 'Winning the lottery' by
options: providing evidence to support an opinion
introducing new ways to solve a problem
providing an example to explain a main idea
describing events in the order that they take place

question_text: Lines 49 through 53 support which of the following claims?
options: The use of glyphosate should be stopped because the herbicide has proven to be a failure.
The only way to prevent weeds from resisting herbicides is to change the DNA of weeds.
Blocking sunlight from reaching the soil is the best way to prevent weed seeds from sprouting.
Fighting weeds is especially difficult because of their ability to evolve to resist threats.

question_text: What is the most likely reason the author describes the seed destructor in lines 64 through 67?
options: to support the idea that farmers need to use a variety of methods to fight weeds
to show how technology is the solution to uncontrollable weed growth
to explain why mechanical methods to fight weeds are better than herbicides
to describe how scientists have found the best way to protect desirable crops

question_text: What is a central idea of 'Excerpt from Katerina's Wish'? Use two details from the story to support your response.
How does Trina's mood change from the beginning to the end of 'Excerpt from Katerina's Wish'? Use two details from the story to support your response.
How does Taylor feel about exploring the woods at the beginning, middle, and end of the story? What causes her feelings to change? Use details from the story to support your response.
Why does the relationship between Julianna and her father change? Use two details from the story to support your response.

How does the father's idea that Julianna 'needed to start looking at the whole landscape' (line 32) relate to his description of a painting in lines 46 through 49? Use two details from the story to support your response.
What is a central idea of 'A Universal Language: Futbol 4 Dreams'? Use two details from the article to support your response.
In 'Recycling Electronic Waste,' why are the results of the survey (lines 27 through 31) important? Use two details from the article to support your response.
What is the author's point of view about electronic waste in the article 'Recycling Electronic Waste'? Use two details from the article to support your response.
What personal characteristics do Alex and the Iribarne sisters share? How did these qualities help them reach their goals? Use details from both articles to support your response.
